context: Thus, even with the current most effective treatment regimens, approximately 20% of patients fail to eradicate the infection. It is well known that bacterial susceptibility to antibiotics and compliance with the prescribed treatment are the most relevant negative predictive factors. However, other factors, such as the extent of the infection within the stomach, have been suggested to influence H. pylori eradication although this association remains controversial. The urea breath test is a non-invasive, simple and safe test, which provides excellent accuracy both for the initial diagnosis of H. pylori infection and for the confirmation of its eradication after treatment. Since the numeric result of the 13C-urea breath test is a function of total urease activity within the stomach, it has been suggested to use this test as a quantitative indicator for the density of gastric H. pylori colonisation. Several authors have studied whether a correlation exists between 13C-urea breath test values prior to treatment and the response to H. pylori eradication therapy, and have concluded that the bacterial density, as assessed by urease activity, is an important factor in predicting H. pylori eradication [5–13], although others disagree with this conclusion. Furthermore, it has been suggested that the H. pylori eradication rate of the rescue regimen is higher for patients with a lower 13C-urea breath test value after the first-line treatment.
